questions.description: Neutrophils and monocytes differ from each other in all of the following except :

options.description: The shape of their nuclei in mature form
Their contribution to total WBC content of blood
Their mode of action against foreign organisms

questions.content_html:
Both neutrophils and monocytes are crucial white blood cells that help defend the body against foreign invaders. While they both use phagocytosis to engulf and destroy these invaders, they have distinct differences in lifespan, location, and function.

  • Neutrophils are the most abundant type of white blood cell and act as the first line of defense in acute, immediate responses to infection. They have a short lifespan and are primarily found in the bloodstream.

  • Monocytes are less numerous than neutrophils and contribute to long-term immunity and tissue repair. They have a longer lifespan and can circulate in the blood or migrate to tissues, becoming macrophages, which are highly efficient phagocytes capable of engulfing larger particles.

Therefore, the primary difference between neutrophils and monocytes lies in their lifespan, location, and function, not in their mode of action against foreign organisms.

questions.description: Which of the following is correct match w.r.t. component of blood and its normal amount in human blood ?
questions.content_html:
Blood is a special connective tissue that consists of a fluid matrix called plasma and formed elements. The formed elements are Erythrocytes (Red Blood Cells), Leucocytes (White Blood Cells), and Platelets (Thrombocytes).

Red blood cells are the most abundant cells in blood. They contain a red coloured protein called haemoglobin, which helps in the transport of respiratory gases. A healthy adult man has, on an average, 5 million to 5.5 million RBCs per cubic mm of blood. The normal range of haemoglobin in human blood is 12–16 gm/dl of blood.

White blood cells are nucleated and are relatively lesser in number than RBCs. They are responsible for the immune responses of the body.

Platelets are cell fragments produced from megakaryocytes in bone marrow. They release a variety of substances that are involved in the coagulation or clotting of blood.

The ratio of plasma and formed elements in blood is roughly 55% plasma and 45% formed elements.

Answer: The normal range of haemoglobin in human blood is 12–16 gm/dl of blood.

questions.description: The most abundant agranulocyte present in human blood is :
questions.content_html:
Blood is a special connective tissue that circulates throughout the body, carrying oxygen, nutrients, and hormones to cells and removing waste products. It is composed of plasma and formed elements.

Plasma is the fluid portion of blood and is made up of water, proteins, electrolytes, and other dissolved substances.

Formed elements are the cells and cell fragments that are suspended in the plasma. They include:

  • Red blood cells (erythrocytes), which are responsible for carrying oxygen to the body's tissues.
  • White blood cells (leucocytes), which are involved in the immune system and fight infection.
  • Platelets (thrombocytes), which are involved in blood clotting.

Leucocytes are classified into two types: granulocytes and agranulocytes. * Granulocytes include neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils. * Agranulocytes include lymphocytes and monocytes.

The most abundant agranulocyte in human blood is lymphocytes. They are responsible for the immune responses of the body.

questions.description: The least and most abundant WBCs respectively are:
questions.content_html:
White blood cells (WBCs) are essential for fighting infections and foreign invaders. There are five main types of WBCs:

  • Neutrophils: The most abundant type, these cells engulf and destroy bacteria, fungi, and other pathogens.
  • Lymphocytes: The second most abundant type, these cells recognize and target specific pathogens. There are two main types:
    • T lymphocytes: These cells directly attack infected cells and regulate immune responses.
    • B lymphocytes: These cells produce antibodies, which neutralize pathogens.
  • Monocytes: These large cells differentiate into macrophages, which are powerful phagocytic cells.
  • Eosinophils: These cells fight parasitic infections and allergic reactions.
  • Basophils: The least abundant type, these cells release histamine and other inflammatory mediators involved in allergic reactions and inflammation.

The least and most abundant WBCs, respectively, are Basophils and Neutrophils.

questions.description: The granulocyte to arrive first at the site of an infection is :
questions.content_html:
Granulocytes are a type of white blood cell that contain granules in their cytoplasm. They are involved in the immune response and are important for fighting infection.

  • Neutrophils are the most abundant type of granulocyte and are the first to arrive at the site of an infection. They are phagocytic, meaning they engulf and destroy bacteria and other foreign invaders.

  • Eosinophils are involved in fighting parasites and allergic reactions.

  • Basophils are involved in allergic reactions and release histamine and other chemicals that help to fight off infection.

The granulocyte to arrive first at the site of an infection is neutrophil.

questions.description: The normal Albumin/ Globulin ratio is blood is :
questions.content_html:
Blood is a vital connective tissue that carries essential nutrients, oxygen, and hormones throughout the body. It's composed of plasma and formed elements.

Plasma, the fluid matrix of blood, is primarily composed of water, with proteins making up 6-8%. Two key protein groups in plasma are albumin and globulins.

  • Albumin is the most abundant protein in plasma and contributes to osmotic balance, transport, and buffering.
  • Globulins are a diverse group of proteins involved in immune defense, transport, and blood clotting.

The ratio between albumin and globulin in blood is a significant indicator of overall health. The normal Albumin/Globulin ratio in blood is 2:1. This means that for every 2 units of albumin, there is 1 unit of globulin. Changes in this ratio can indicate liver diseases, kidney diseases, inflammation, infection, and malnutrition.

questions.description: Which WBC  has maximum lobs of nucleus ?
questions.content_html:
White blood cells (WBCs), also known as leukocytes, are vital for our immune system, fighting off infections and foreign invaders. They're divided into two main categories:

  • Granulocytes: These cells contain granules in their cytoplasm. Some examples include neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Agranulocytes: Lacking granules in their cytoplasm, this category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

Neutrophils are the most abundant type of WBC, making up 60-65% of the total WBC count. They are a crucial part of the innate immune system, quickly responding to infections by engulfing and destroying bacteria and other harmful microorganisms through phagocytosis.

A key feature of WBCs is their nucleus, which contains the cell's genetic material (DNA) and controls cellular activities.

Neutrophils have a distinctive multi-lobed nucleus, typically with 2-5 lobes. This multi-lobed appearance is a characteristic feature that helps distinguish neutrophils from other types of WBCs.

Therefore, the WBC with the maximum lobes of the nucleus is the Neutrophil.

questions.description: Which of the following factor is not related with delayed blood clotting ?

options.description: Presence of B antigen of RBC

questions.content_html:
Blood is a special connective tissue consisting of a fluid matrix, plasma, and formed elements. Plasma is a straw coloured, viscous fluid constituting nearly 55 per cent of the blood. 90-92 per cent of plasma is water and proteins contribute 6-8 per cent of it. Fibrinogen, globulins and albumins are the major proteins.

Fibrinogens are needed for clotting or coagulation of blood. Globulins primarily are involved in defense mechanisms of the body and the albumins help in osmotic balance. Plasma also contains small amounts of minerals like Na+, Ca++, Mg++, HCO3, Cl-, etc. Glucose, amino acids, lipids, etc., are also present in the plasma as they are always in transit in the body. Factors for coagulation or clotting of blood are also present in the plasma in an inactive form. Plasma without the clotting factors is called serum.

Erythrocytes, leucocytes and platelets are collectively called formed elements. Erythrocytes or red blood cells (RBC) are the most abundant of all the cells in blood. A healthy adult man has, on an average, 5 millions to 5.5 millions of RBCs mm³ of blood.

Platelets also called thrombocytes, are cell fragments produced from megakaryocytes (special cells in the bone marrow). Blood normally contains 1,500,00-3,500,00 platelets mm-3. Platelets can release a variety of substances most of which are involved in the coagulation or clotting of blood.

The presence of B antigen of RBC is not related to delayed blood clotting.

questions.description: If a person undergoes a road accident and during blood analysis it is found that both antibody A and B are present in blood. The blood of which of the following blood group is used for blood transfusion?
questions.content_html:
A blood transfusion requires matching the donor's blood type with the recipient's to avoid a serious reaction called agglutination. This reaction occurs when antibodies in the recipient's plasma react with the donor's antigens, causing the red blood cells to clump together and block blood vessels.

If a person undergoes a road accident and blood analysis reveals the presence of both antibody A and B in their blood, they have blood group O. This is because blood group O individuals lack both antigen A and B on their red blood cells, but their plasma contains both antibody A and B. Therefore, only blood group O can be safely transfused to this person, as it won't trigger an agglutination reaction.

questions.description: If the plasma of a person contains 'B' antibodies and the RBCs have 'Rh' and 'A' antigens, the blood of the person should not be transfused to anyone with the blood group :
questions.content_html:
The blood of the person should not be transfused to anyone with the blood group A negative.

Here's why:

  • The person has type A positive blood: This means their red blood cells have the A antigen and the Rh factor.
  • Their plasma contains B antibodies: This is a characteristic of type A blood.
  • A negative blood lacks the Rh factor: If the person's blood is transfused to an A negative recipient, the recipient's body will recognize the Rh factor as foreign.

This could trigger the production of anti-Rh antibodies in the recipient's blood, leading to a serious reaction called hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN).

questions.description:
Consider the following statements regarding double blood circulation :
 (A) Pulmonary circulation starts by the pumping of deoxygenated blood from right ventricle into lungs and its return in oxygenated form to right atrium. 
 (B) Systemic circulation starts with pumping of oxygenated blood from left ventricle through aorta to all body systems and return of the blood in deoxygenated form into left atrium through veins. 
 Select the correct answer from the given options :
questions.content_html:

questions.description: Which of the following cannot be taken as a feature of open type circulatory system ?

options.description: Well regulated blood supply to different organs
Blood returns to the heart slowly

questions.content_html:
An open circulatory system is a type of circulatory system in which blood is not always contained within blood vessels, but flows through open spaces in the body called sinuses. It's characteristic of some invertebrates such as insects and crustaceans.

Here are some key features of an open circulatory system:

  • Blood is not always contained within blood vessels: Instead, it flows through open spaces called sinuses.
  • Blood supply to different organs is not well regulated: This is because the blood is not always flowing directly to the organs, and the pressure in the sinuses can vary.
  • Blood pressure is low: This is because the blood is not confined to blood vessels and can flow more freely.
  • Heart is less powerful than in closed circulatory systems: This is because it does not need to pump blood with as much force to overcome the resistance of blood vessels.
  • Blood volume is generally low: This is because the blood is not confined to blood vessels and can spread out into the sinuses.

Key point: The statement "Well regulated blood supply to different organs" is not a feature of an open circulatory system.

questions.description: Mark the odd one w.r.t. the incomplete double circulation :
questions.content_html:
The circulatory system plays a vital role in transporting essential substances throughout the body. Different animal groups have developed unique circulatory systems to meet their specific needs.

Fishes are the odd ones out when it comes to incomplete double circulation. Unlike amphibians and reptiles, which possess an incomplete double circulation system where oxygenated and deoxygenated blood mix in the ventricle, fishes have a single circulation system. This system involves blood passing through the heart only once during a complete circuit.

The single circulation in fishes is less efficient compared to the double circulation found in birds and mammals. This is because oxygenated and deoxygenated blood mix, resulting in less oxygen delivered to the body.

questions.description: Which among the following is last to get depolarised in a cardiac cycle ?
questions.content_html:
The cardiac cycle is the sequence of events that happens in the heart with every beat. These events include the contraction and relaxation of the heart chambers, the opening and closing of the heart valves, and the flow of blood through the heart.

The heart is a muscular organ responsible for pumping blood throughout the body. It is made up of four chambers: the right atrium, the right ventricle, the left atrium, and the left ventricle.

The electrical activation of the heart muscle cells is known as depolarization. It occurs due to the movement of ions across the cell membrane. The process of depolarization starts at the Sinoatrial (SA) node, located in the right atrium. It is the heart's pacemaker and initiates the electrical impulse that triggers each heartbeat. The electrical impulse travels to the Atrioventricular (AV) node, located in the septum between the atria. The impulse then passes through the Bundle of His, which is a specialized bundle of fibers located in the septum. Finally, the impulse travels through the Purkinje fibers to the ventricular muscle cells.

The Purkinje fibers are the last to get depolarised in a cardiac cycle. This is because they are the final pathway for the electrical impulse to reach the ventricular muscle cells, which are responsible for the contraction of the ventricles.

questions.description: The blood pressure of a person is measured as 130/75 mm Hg. His pulse pressure is :
questions.content_html:
Blood pressure is the force that blood exerts on the walls of blood vessels. It is measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg) and is typically expressed as two numbers:

  • Systolic pressure: The pressure in the arteries when the heart beats (contracts).
  • Diastolic pressure: The pressure in the arteries when the heart is at rest (between beats).

Pulse Pressure is the difference between the systolic and diastolic pressures. It reflects the elasticity of the arteries and the volume of blood pumped by the heart.

Example: A blood pressure reading of 130/75 mmHg means:

  • Systolic pressure: 130 mmHg
  • Diastolic pressure: 75 mmHg

The pulse pressure for this reading would be: * 130 - 75 = 55 mmHg

Blood Circulation is the continuous movement of blood throughout the body. It is essential for delivering oxygen and nutrients to tissues and removing waste products. The circulatory system consists of:

  • Heart: A muscular pump that propels blood throughout the body.
  • Blood vessels: A network of tubes that carry blood to and from the heart.
  • Blood: The fluid that circulates through the body.

Here's a breakdown of blood circulation:

  1. Oxygen-poor blood returns from the body to the right atrium of the heart.
  2. The right atrium pumps the blood to the right ventricle.
  3. The right ventricle pumps the blood to the lungs through the pulmonary artery.
  4. In the lungs, carbon dioxide is released from the blood and oxygen is absorbed.
  5. Oxygen-rich blood returns from the lungs to the left atrium of the heart.
  6. The left atrium pumps the blood to the left ventricle.
  7. The left ventricle pumps the blood to the body through the aorta.
  8. The blood travels throughout the body, delivering oxygen and nutrients and picking up waste products.
  9. The cycle repeats.

Understanding the relationship between blood pressure, pulse pressure, and blood circulation is essential for maintaining good health. Regular monitoring of blood pressure can help detect potential health issues, such as hypertension.

For a blood pressure reading of 130/75 mm Hg, the pulse pressure is 55 mm Hg.

questions.description: The part of conducting system present in ventricular wall of human heart is :
questions.content_html:
The human heart has a specialized system of tissues called the conducting system that controls the rhythm of the heartbeats. This system ensures that the heart beats in a coordinated manner, ensuring efficient blood flow throughout the body.

The conducting system starts with the sino-atrial node (SAN), located in the right atrium. This acts as the heart's pacemaker, initiating the heartbeat and setting the rhythm. The electrical impulse generated by the SAN spreads through the atria, causing them to contract and pump blood into the ventricles.

The impulse then reaches the atrioventricular node (AVN), located in the lower right atrium, near the septum between the atria and the ventricles. The AVN delays the signal for a short period, allowing the ventricles to fill with blood before they contract.

After the AVN, the impulse travels through the atrioventricular bundle (AV bundle), also called the bundle of His. This bundle descends down the septum between the ventricles and then splits into right and left branches. These branches further divide into smaller fibers called Purkinje fibers, which spread throughout the ventricular walls.

The Purkinje fibers are specialized fibers that conduct the electrical impulse very rapidly, ensuring that both ventricles contract almost simultaneously. This synchronized contraction is essential for efficient pumping of blood.

Therefore, the Purkinje fibers are the part of the conducting system present in the ventricular wall of the human heart.

questions.description: The pacesetter in the heart is called :
questions.content_html:
The heart is a muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body. It is composed of four chambers: two atria and two ventricles. The atria are the upper chambers of the heart, and they receive blood from the body. The ventricles are the lower chambers of the heart, and they pump blood out to the body.

The heart beats rhythmically, and this rhythm is controlled by a specialized tissue called the nodal tissue. The sinoatrial node (SAN), located in the right atrium, is the primary pacemaker of the heart. It generates electrical impulses that spread throughout the heart, causing the atria to contract and pump blood into the ventricles.

The atrioventricular node (AVN), located in the lower right atrium, is another important part of the heart's electrical conduction system. It receives electrical impulses from the SAN and delays them slightly before passing them on to the ventricles. This delay allows the atria to empty completely before the ventricles contract.

The pacemaker of the heart is the sinoatrial node (SAN).

The left ventricle pumps blood to the systemic circulation, which delivers oxygenated blood to all parts of the body except the lungs. This is a high-pressure system because the blood must travel a much greater distance and overcome more resistance compared to the pulmonary circulation.

questions.description: An adult human with average health has systolic and diastolic pressures as :
questions.content_html:
Blood pressure is the force of blood pushing against the walls of your arteries. It's measured in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg).

There are two parts to a blood pressure reading:

  • Systolic pressure is the pressure when your heart beats and pumps blood into your arteries (the top number).
  • Diastolic pressure is the pressure when your heart relaxes between beats (the bottom number).

A healthy adult typically has a blood pressure of around 120/80 mm Hg. This means their systolic pressure is 120 mm Hg and their diastolic pressure is 80 mm Hg.

Blood pressure is a crucial indicator of heart health. High blood pressure (hypertension) increases the risk of heart disease, stroke, and other health problems. Low blood pressure (hypotension) can also be problematic, causing dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting.

Blood pressure is influenced by a variety of factors, including:

  • Heart: The heart's strength and rate of contraction.
  • Circulation: The volume and flow of blood.
  • Blood vessels: The diameter and elasticity of blood vessels.

Understanding blood pressure is essential for maintaining good health. Regular blood pressure checks and lifestyle modifications (exercise, diet, stress management) can help manage blood pressure and reduce the risk of associated health problems.

questions.description: Time interval between the closure of semilunar valve and closure of AV valve is :
questions.content_html:
The heart is a muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body. It has four chambers: two upper chambers called atria and two lower chambers called ventricles. The atria receive blood from the body (right atrium) and lungs (left atrium), while the ventricles pump blood to the lungs (right ventricle) and body (left ventricle).

The cardiac cycle is the sequence of events that occurs during one heartbeat. It consists of two phases: systole (contraction) and diastole (relaxation).

During systole, the atria contract first, pushing blood into the ventricles. Then, the ventricles contract, pushing blood out to the lungs (right ventricle) or body (left ventricle).

During diastole, the chambers of the heart relax, allowing blood to fill the atria.

The semilunar valves are located at the exit of the ventricles, preventing backflow of blood into the ventricles when the ventricles relax.

The atrioventricular (AV) valves are located between the atria and ventricles, preventing backflow of blood into the atria when the ventricles contract.

The time interval between the closure of the semilunar valve and the closure of the AV valve is called the isovolumetric relaxation period.

The time interval between the closure of the semilunar valve and the closure of the AV valve is called the isovolumetric relaxation period, and its duration varies depending on factors such as heart rate and age.

questions.description: The course of blood from the heart to the lungs and back to the heart is called :
questions.content_html:
The course of blood from the heart to the lungs and back to the heart is called pulmonary circulation.

Here's how it works:

  1. Deoxygenated blood (blood low in oxygen) travels from the body back to the heart and enters the right atrium.
  2. The right atrium pumps the blood into the right ventricle.
  3. The right ventricle pumps the deoxygenated blood to the lungs through the pulmonary artery.
  4. In the lungs, the blood picks up oxygen and releases carbon dioxide.
  5. The now oxygenated blood returns to the heart through the pulmonary veins and enters the left atrium.
  6. The left atrium pumps the blood into the left ventricle.
  7. The left ventricle pumps the oxygenated blood out to the body through the aorta.

This process ensures a constant supply of oxygen to the body and removes waste. It repeats continuously to maintain the health of the body.

questions.description: Which of the following sequence is truly a systemic circulation pathway ?

options.description: Right ventricle →  Pulmonary aorta → Tissues → Pulmonary veins →  Left auricle
Right auricle →  Left ventricle →  Aorta → Tissues →  Veins → Right auricle
Left auricle →  Left ventricle →  Pulmonary aorta → Tissues →  Right auricle
Left ventricle →  Aorta → Arteries →  Tissues → Veins → Right auricle

questions.content_html:
Blood Circulation

Blood circulation is the continuous movement of blood throughout the body, driven by the heart. It ensures that every cell receives oxygen and nutrients while removing waste products. This process involves a complex network of blood vessels and a powerful pump - the heart.

The Heart Chambers

The heart is a four-chambered organ, divided into two atria (upper chambers) and two ventricles (lower chambers). Each atrium receives blood, while each ventricle pumps blood out. - Right atrium: Receives deoxygenated blood from the body through the superior and inferior vena cava. - Right ventricle: Pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs through the pulmonary artery. - Left atrium: Receives oxygenated blood from the lungs through the pulmonary veins. - Left ventricle: Pumps oxygenated blood to the body through the aorta.

Blood Vessels

Blood travels through a network of blood vessels, classified into three types: - Arteries: Carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to the body. They have thick, elastic walls to withstand high pressure. - Veins: Carry deoxygenated blood back to the heart. They have thinner walls than arteries and contain valves to prevent backflow. - Capillaries: Tiny, thin-walled vessels that connect arteries and veins. They facilitate exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissues.

Circulation Pathway

The circulatory system operates in two distinct circuits:

  • Pulmonary circulation: The flow of deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs and back, for oxygenation. This pathway starts in the right ventricle, moves through the pulmonary arteries to the lungs, and returns to the left atrium through the pulmonary veins.
  • Systemic circulation: The flow of oxygenated blood from the heart to the body and back, for nutrient delivery and waste removal. This pathway starts in the left ventricle, moves through the aorta to the body, and returns to the right atrium through the vena cava.

Systemic Circulation Pathway

The correct systemic circulation pathway is: Left ventricle → Aorta → Arteries → Tissues → Veins → Right auricle

This sequence accurately reflects the movement of oxygenated blood from the left ventricle, through the major artery (aorta), then to smaller arteries that branch out to the tissues, and finally back to the heart through veins that converge into the superior and inferior vena cava, ending in the right auricle.

questions.description:
During ventricular systole : 
 a. Blood gets filled in atria from vena cava  
 b.  Atrio–ventricular valves get opened  
 c. Semilunar valves get opened  
 d.  About 70 ml blood is pumped by each ventricle into large arteries normally
questions.content_html:
During ventricular systole:

  • Semilunar valves get opened
  • About 70 ml blood is pumped by each ventricle into large arteries normally

The reason why these options are correct and the other options are incorrect is that during ventricular systole, the ventricles contract and pump blood out of the heart. To do this, the semilunar valves must be open to allow blood to flow from the ventricles into the aorta and pulmonary artery. Each ventricle typically pumps about 70 ml of blood into the large arteries during a normal contraction. The atrioventricular valves are closed during ventricular systole to prevent backflow of blood into the atria. The atria fill with blood from the vena cava during ventricular diastole, when the ventricles relax.

questions.description: In human oxygenated blood flows from :

options.description: Left auricle to left ventricle during auricular systole
Right auricle to right ventricle during ventricular systole
Right ventricle to aorta during ventricular systole
Pulmonary vein to left auricle during auricular systole

questions.content_html:
In the human circulatory system, oxygenated blood flows from the left auricle (left atrium) to the left ventricle during auricular (atrial) systole.

Here's why:

  • Oxygenated Blood: This blood has been enriched with oxygen in the lungs.
  • Left Auricle (Atrium): The left atrium is the heart chamber that receives oxygenated blood from the lungs.
  • Left Ventricle: The left ventricle is the powerful chamber of the heart that pumps oxygenated blood out to the rest of the body.
  • Auricular (Atrial) Systole: This refers to the contraction phase of the atria. During atrial systole, the left atrium contracts, forcing the oxygenated blood through the mitral valve into the left ventricle.

Let's break down the blood circulation process:

  1. Oxygen-Poor Blood: Blood returns to the heart from the body, carrying carbon dioxide and waste products. This blood enters the right atrium.
  2. Right Ventricle: The right ventricle pumps this oxygen-poor blood to the lungs.
  3. Lungs: The lungs exchange carbon dioxide for oxygen, and the blood becomes oxygenated.
  4. Left Atrium: Oxygen-rich blood returns to the heart and enters the left atrium.
  5. Left Ventricle: The left ventricle pumps this oxygenated blood out to the rest of the body.
  6. The Cycle Repeats: This process continues in a continuous loop, ensuring that the body's cells are constantly supplied with oxygen and nutrients.

questions.description:
Read the following statements (A–D) : 
 A. RBCs are the most abundant of all the cells in blood 
 B. A healthy adult man has on an average 5 billions to 5.5 billions of RBCs mm‾³ of blood 
 C. RBCs are formed in liver in the adults 
 D. RBCs are devoid of nucleus in mammals and are biconcave in shape 
 How many of the above statements are incorrect?
questions.content_html:
Red blood cells (RBCs), also known as erythrocytes, are the most abundant type of cell in the blood. They are responsible for transporting oxygen from the lungs to the body's tissues and carbon dioxide back to the lungs.

Key features of RBCs:

  • Shape: Biconcave discs, which increases their surface area for gas exchange.
  • Nucleus: In mammals, mature RBCs lack a nucleus, which allows for more space for hemoglobin.
  • Hemoglobin: RBCs contain hemoglobin, a protein that binds to oxygen and gives blood its red color.

Blood is a specialized connective tissue that circulates throughout the body, carrying vital substances and removing waste products. It consists of:

  • Plasma: A straw-colored fluid that makes up about 55% of blood volume. It contains water, proteins, nutrients, electrolytes, hormones, and waste products.
  • Formed elements: These are the cells and cell fragments found in blood:
    • Red blood cells (RBCs): Carry oxygen.
    • White blood cells (WBCs): Fight infection and disease.
    • Platelets: Help with blood clotting.

Blood cells are constantly being produced in a process called hematopoiesis. In adults, this primarily occurs in the red bone marrow. Hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow differentiate into various types of blood cells.

Hemoglobin is a protein found in red blood cells that binds to oxygen and carries it throughout the body. It consists of four subunits, each containing a heme group, which contains an iron atom. The iron atom in heme is what binds to oxygen.

Here's the answer to the question:

A. RBCs are the most abundant of all the cells in blood. This statement is TRUE.

B. A healthy adult man has on an average 5 billions to 5.5 billions of RBCs mm‾³ of blood. This statement is TRUE.

C. RBCs are formed in liver in the adults. This statement is FALSE. RBCs are formed in the red bone marrow in adults.

D. RBCs are devoid of nucleus in mammals and are biconcave in shape. This statement is TRUE.

Therefore, two statements (C) are incorrect.

questions.description: Pulmonary veins are those which :

options.description: Carry deoxygenated blood from lungs to heart
Carry oxygenated blood from lungs to heart
Carry deoxygenated blood from heart to lung
Carry oxygenated blood from heart to lungs

questions.content_html:
The pulmonary veins are the vessels that carry oxygen-rich blood from the lungs to the heart.

Here's how it works:

  1. Lungs: The lungs take in oxygen from the air and release carbon dioxide as waste.
  2. Oxygenated Blood: Oxygen moves from the air sacs in the lungs into tiny blood vessels called capillaries, and attaches to red blood cells. This makes the blood oxygenated.
  3. Pulmonary Veins: The pulmonary veins carry this oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.
  4. Heart: The heart pumps the oxygenated blood to the rest of the body.

The pulmonary veins play a vital role in circulating oxygenated blood throughout the body.

The autonomic nervous system, hormones, and other factors can influence these two components, effectively regulating cardiac output.

questions.description: The wall of arteries and veins are made up of these layers. Which of the following is the main difference in the structure of arteries and veins ?

options.description: Tunica media is made up of collagen fibres only in viens
Tunica externa is made up of endothelium in veins
Tunica intima is made up of smooth muslces in viens
Tunica media is comparatively thin in veins

questions.content_html:
The walls of arteries and veins are composed of three layers: tunica intima, tunica media, and tunica externa.

The main difference between arteries and veins lies in the thickness of the tunica media.

Arteries have a thicker tunica media compared to veins. This is due to the higher pressure of blood flowing through them, which requires a thicker layer to withstand the pressure and maintain their shape.

Veins, on the other hand, carry blood back to the heart at a lower pressure. They rely more on the surrounding muscles to help propel blood back to the heart, so they have a thinner tunica media.

questions.description: In what way pulmonary artery is different from pulmonary vein ?
questions.content_html:
The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs. It has a thicker wall to withstand the higher pressure of blood being pumped from the heart.

The pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood from the lungs back to the heart. It has a thinner wall because the pressure of blood returning to the heart is lower.

The pulmonary artery is different from the pulmonary vein because its wall is thicker.

questions.description: Fastest distribution of some injectible material/medicine with no risk of any kind can be achieved by injecting it into the :
Rate of heart beat and cardiac output can be increased by :

options.description: Neural signal through the sympathetic nerves

questions.content_html:
Heart rate and cardiac output are both essential for maintaining adequate blood flow throughout the body. These two measures can be influenced by various factors, including:

  • Increased physical activity: When you exercise, your muscles demand more oxygen and nutrients. To meet this demand, your heart beats faster (increased heart rate) and pumps out more blood per beat (increased stroke volume), resulting in a higher cardiac output.

  • Stress: Stress triggers the body's "fight or flight" response, which involves a surge of adrenaline and other hormones. These hormones cause the heart to beat faster and stronger, leading to increased heart rate and cardiac output.

Therefore, both increased physical activity and stress can lead to higher heart rate and cardiac output.

questions.description: A portal system is one in which :

options.description: A vein starts from an organ and ends up in heart
A vein starts from an organ and ends up in another organ
A vein starts from heart and ends up in lungs

questions.content_html:
A portal system is one in which a vein starts from an organ and ends up in another organ without going through the heart first. This is a specialized type of blood circulation that acts as a "filter" or "processing center" between two specific organs, facilitating a vital function.

For example, in the Hepatic Portal System, the Hepatic Portal Vein collects blood from the digestive system, which is rich in nutrients absorbed from food. This vein doesn't go directly to the heart, but instead leads to the liver. In the liver, the blood undergoes processing: nutrients are stored, toxins are filtered out, and the blood is prepared for circulation throughout the rest of the body.

questions.content_html:
Angina pectoris is chest pain caused by a temporary reduction in blood flow to the heart muscle. This occurs when the heart muscle doesn't receive enough oxygen, which can be caused by a narrowing of the coronary arteries.

The heart muscle needs a constant supply of oxygen-rich blood to function properly. When the blood flow to the heart muscle is reduced, the heart muscle can't work as efficiently, and this can cause chest pain.

The answer is Both (a) & (c).

questions.content_html:
Phagocytosis is the process by which certain cells engulf and destroy foreign particles, such as bacteria, viruses, and cellular debris. Cells that exhibit phagocytic activity are called phagocytes.

White blood cells, also known as leukocytes, are a crucial part of the immune system, defending the body against infection and disease. They are found in the blood and lymphatic system and play a vital role in:

  • Identifying and destroying pathogens: WBCs recognize and eliminate invading microorganisms like bacteria, viruses, and fungi.
  • Removing cellular debris: They clear up dead or damaged cells, contributing to tissue repair.
  • Immune regulation: WBCs help control and regulate the immune response, preventing excessive inflammation or autoimmune reactions.

There are several types of WBCs, each with specialized functions:

  • Neutrophils: These are the most abundant type of WBC and are the first responders to infection. They are highly phagocytic and effectively engulf and destroy bacteria.
  • Monocytes: Monocytes are larger than neutrophils and have a longer lifespan. They migrate to tissues and differentiate into macrophages, which are powerful phagocytes that engulf larger particles and play a key role in chronic infections.
  • Basophils: Basophils are the least common type of WBC. They are involved in allergic reactions and release histamine, a chemical that triggers inflammation. Unlike neutrophils and monocytes, they do not exhibit phagocytic activity.

Basophils do not have phagocytic activity. Their primary role is in allergic reactions and inflammation. They release histamine and other chemicals to mediate these responses.

questions.description: One of the common symptoms observed in people infected with Dengue fever is :
questions.content_html: Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection that can cause a significant decrease in platelet count. Platelets are tiny cell fragments in the blood that play a crucial role in blood clotting. A low platelet count can lead to excessive bleeding, putting patients at risk for life-threatening complications.

questions.description: Which among the followings is correct during each cardiac cycle?

options.description: The volume of blood pumped out by the Rt and Lt ventricles is same
The volume of blood pumped out by the Rt and Lt ventricles is different
The volume of blood received by each atrium is different
The volume of blood received by the aorta and pulmonary artery is different

questions.content_html:
The cardiac cycle is the rhythmic sequence of events in the heart that occurs during one heartbeat. It is composed of two phases: systole and diastole.

  • Systole is the contraction phase of the heart, during which blood is pumped out of the ventricles.
  • Diastole is the relaxation phase of the heart, during which the ventricles fill with blood.

The cardiac cycle begins with atrial systole, which pumps blood from the atria into the ventricles. This is followed by ventricular systole, which pumps blood out of the ventricles and into the arteries. Finally, the heart relaxes during diastole, allowing the ventricles to fill with blood again.

The ventricles are the two lower chambers of the heart. The right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs, while the left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood to the rest of the body.

The volume of blood pumped out by the right and left ventricles is the same during each cardiac cycle. This is because the heart is a closed system, and the amount of blood that enters the heart must equal the amount that leaves it.

The parasympathetic nervous system, the "rest and digest" system, slows heart rate and decreases stroke volume.

questions.description: Mark the pair of substances among the following which is essential for coagulation of blood :
questions.content_html:
Blood coagulation, also known as blood clotting, is a complex process that stops bleeding after an injury. It involves a cascade of reactions that ultimately leads to the formation of a fibrin clot, which seals the wound.

Two key components of blood coagulation are calcium ions and platelet factors.

Here's how the process works:

  1. When a blood vessel is injured, platelets adhere to the damaged surface and release platelet factors, including platelet factor 3.

  2. These factors, along with other clotting factors in the blood, activate a cascade of reactions.

  3. Calcium ions play a crucial role in this cascade, facilitating the conversion of prothrombin (an inactive enzyme) into thrombin (an active enzyme).

  4. Thrombin then converts fibrinogen into fibrin.

  5. Fibrin fibers form a meshwork that traps blood cells and platelets, creating a stable clot that stops bleeding.

questions.description: ECG depicts the depolarisation and repolarisation processes during the cardiac cycle. In the ECG of a normal healthy individual one of the following waves is not represented :
questions.content_html:
The ECG, or electrocardiogram, records the electrical activity of the heart. It shows the depolarization and repolarization processes that happen during the cardiac cycle, which is the sequence of events with each heartbeat.

Here are the waves that an ECG shows:

  • P wave: The depolarization of the atria, the upper chambers of the heart. This triggers atrial contraction.
  • QRS complex: The depolarization of the ventricles, the lower chambers of the heart. This triggers ventricular contraction.
  • T wave: The repolarization of the ventricles. This is the recovery period for the ventricles after contraction.

The repolarization of the atria is not represented in a normal ECG. The reason is that the electrical event is small, and it is masked by the much larger QRS complex.

questions.description: Which one of the following types of cells lack nucleus in humans ?
questions.content_html: Blood is a special connective tissue that consists of a fluid matrix called plasma and formed elements. Formed elements are cells and cell fragments suspended in plasma. One of the major types of formed elements is erythrocytes, also known as red blood cells. Erythrocytes are responsible for the transport of oxygen throughout the body. Unlike most cells in the human body, erythrocytes lack a nucleus, which allows them to pack in more hemoglobin for oxygen transport.

questions.description: Which one of the following blood cells is involved in antibody production ?
questions.content_html:
Blood is a vital fluid that circulates throughout the body, transporting essential nutrients, oxygen, and removing waste products. It's made up of plasma, a liquid component containing proteins and dissolved substances, and formed elements, which are cells and cell fragments suspended in plasma.

Formed elements play crucial roles in different bodily functions:

  • Red blood cells (RBCs), responsible for transporting oxygen throughout the body, contain hemoglobin, an iron-containing protein that binds to oxygen.
  • White blood cells (WBCs), part of the immune system, fight off infections and protect the body from foreign invaders.
    • Neutrophils engulf and destroy bacteria.
    • Eosinophils combat parasitic infections and allergic reactions.
    • Basophils release histamine and heparin, involved in inflammatory responses.
    • Lymphocytes are central to adaptive immunity, recognizing and targeting specific pathogens.
      • B-lymphocytes produce antibodies, proteins that specifically bind to and neutralize antigens (foreign substances).
      • T-lymphocytes regulate the immune response, directly attacking infected cells and activating other immune cells.
  • Platelets, small cell fragments that play a crucial role in blood clotting, stopping bleeding.

The blood cell involved in antibody production is the B-lymphocyte. B-cells differentiate into plasma cells, which synthesize and release antibodies. These antibodies are crucial for targeting and neutralizing specific pathogens during the immune response.

questions.description: The second heart sound (dub) is associated with the closure of :
questions.content_html: The second heart sound ("dub") is associated with the closure of the semilunar valves. The semilunar valves are located between the ventricles and the aorta/pulmonary artery. They prevent backflow from the pulmonary artery and aorta to the ventricles. At the end of ventricular systole, as the pressure in the ventricles falls below the pressure in the pulmonary artery and aorta, the semilunar valves close, creating the "dub" sound.

questions.description: What would be the cardiac output of a person having 72 heart beats per minute and a stroke volume of 50 ml?
questions.content_html:
Blood is a special connective tissue that continuously circulates throughout our body, delivering oxygen and nutrients to cells while removing waste products. This continuous flow is called blood circulation.

The heart is the organ responsible for pumping blood. It does this by contracting and relaxing, which is measured by two factors: * Heart Rate: The number of times the heart beats per minute. * Stroke Volume: The volume of blood pumped out by the heart with each beat.

Cardiac Output represents the total volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute. It is calculated by multiplying heart rate and stroke volume:

Cardiac Output = Heart Rate x Stroke Volume

For example, a person with a heart rate of 72 beats per minute and a stroke volume of 50 ml would have a cardiac output of:

Cardiac Output = 72 beats/minute x 50 ml/beat = 3600 ml/minute

Therefore, the cardiac output of a person with 72 heart beats per minute and a stroke volume of 50 ml is 3600 mL.

questions.description:
Read the following statements and choose the correct option :
 Statement A :  Atria receive blood from all parts of the body which subsequently flows to ventricles.
 Statement B : Action potential generated at sinoatrial node passes from atria to ventricles.

options.description: Statement A is correct but statement B is incorrect
Statement B is correct but statement A is incorrect
Both statements A and B are correct
Both statements A and B are incorrect

questions.content_html:
The heart is a powerful pump that circulates blood throughout the body. Here's how it works:

The Heart's Chambers

  • Atria: The heart has two upper chambers called atria. They receive blood from the body (right atrium) and the lungs (left atrium).
  • Ventricles: The two lower chambers, called ventricles, are responsible for pumping blood out to the body (left ventricle) and the lungs (right ventricle).

The Heartbeat: A Rhythm of Electrical Signals

The heartbeat is initiated by a specialized group of cells called the sinoatrial node (SAN), located in the right atrium. The SAN acts as the heart's pacemaker, generating electrical impulses (action potentials) that spread throughout the heart. These action potentials trigger the heart muscle to contract, causing the chambers to pump blood.

The Cardiac Cycle: A Series of Coordinated Events

One complete heartbeat is called a cardiac cycle. Here's what happens:

  1. Atrial Systole: The atria contract, pumping blood into the ventricles.
  2. Ventricular Systole: The ventricles contract, forcing blood out to the body and lungs.
  3. Diastole: All four chambers relax, allowing blood to refill the atria.

Blood Circulation: A Continuous Flow

The heart's rhythmic contractions drive the blood circulation, a continuous loop that delivers oxygen and nutrients to the body's tissues while removing waste products.

Two Major Circuits:

  • Pulmonary Circulation: Blood travels from the right ventricle to the lungs, picks up oxygen, and releases carbon dioxide. Oxygenated blood then returns to the left atrium.
  • Systemic Circulation: Oxygenated blood leaves the left ventricle and travels throughout the body, delivering oxygen and nutrients. Deoxygenated blood then returns to the right atrium.

Double Circulation: Efficiency in Action

Humans have double circulation, meaning blood passes through the heart twice during each complete circuit. This system ensures efficient delivery of oxygenated blood to all parts of the body.

Key Points:

  • Atria receive blood from both the body and the lungs, and they pump blood into the ventricles.
  • The action potential generated by the sinoatrial node spreads through the heart, causing the atria and ventricles to contract in a coordinated sequence.
  • The heart's rhythmic contractions drive the continuous flow of blood through the circulatory system, delivering oxygen and nutrients and removing waste products.

Both statements A and B are correct:

  • Statement A: Atria receive blood from all parts of the body, which subsequently flows to ventricles.
  • Statement B: Action potential generated at the sinoatrial node passes from atria to ventricles.

Match the terms given under column-I with their functions given under column-II and select the answer from the options given below :
Column-I 
A. Lymphatic system
B. Pulmonary vein 
C. Thrombocytes 
D. Lymphocytes
Column-II
i. Carries oxygenated blood
ii. Immune response
iii.To drain back the tissue fluid to the circulatory  
iv. Coagulation of blood
questions.content_html:
The lymphatic system is a network of vessels and tissues that helps to drain back tissue fluid to the circulatory system and is also involved in the immune response. Lymph is a colorless fluid containing specialized lymphocytes that are responsible for the immune responses of the body.

The pulmonary vein is a blood vessel that carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium of the heart.

Thrombocytes, also known as platelets, are cell fragments that are produced from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow. They play a vital role in the coagulation or clotting of blood.

Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell that is responsible for the immune responses of the body. There are two major types of lymphocytes: B lymphocytes and T lymphocytes. Both types play a crucial role in the immune response.

The blood circulation is the process by which blood is transported throughout the body. The human circulatory system consists of a muscular chambered heart, a network of closed branching blood vessels and blood, the fluid which is circulated. There are two main types of circulation in humans: pulmonary circulation and systemic circulation.

questions.description: G–6–P dehydrogenase deficiency is accociated with haemolysis of :
questions.content_html: G-6-P dehydrogenase deficiency is a genetic disorder that causes red blood cells (RBCs) to break down, also known as hemolysis. This happens because RBCs lack the crucial enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, which is essential for protecting them from oxidative stress. Without this enzyme, RBCs are more vulnerable to damage, leading to their breakdown.

questions.description: If  RBCs are placed in distilled water, the corpuscles will :
questions.content_html:
Red blood cells, the tiny heroes of our bodies, are responsible for carrying oxygen to our tissues. They have a unique biconcave shape that allows them to squeeze through tiny blood vessels and maximize their surface area for efficient gas exchange.

Now imagine placing these red blood cells in pure, distilled water. Distilled water is like a giant, empty pool, with very few dissolved substances. In contrast, the inside of a red blood cell is bustling with dissolved salts and proteins, making it a much more crowded space.

This difference in concentration creates a powerful force called osmosis. Water, always eager to balance things out, rushes from the less crowded distilled water into the more crowded red blood cell. Think of it like water rushing to fill an empty pool.

As more and more water enters the red blood cell, it begins to swell, like a balloon being inflated. But the cell membrane can only stretch so far. Eventually, the pressure inside becomes too much, and the cell bursts, releasing its contents into the surrounding water. This is called cell lysis.

So, if you put red blood cells in distilled water, the corpuscles will burst due to the influx of water caused by osmosis, leading to cell lysis.

questions.description: Which of the following blood vessels bypass are present in the circulatory system before birth ?
questions.content_html:
Before birth, a baby's lungs aren't functional, so the circulatory system has two special bypasses to ensure oxygenated blood reaches the body:

(A) Ductus arteriosus: This blood vessel connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, bypassing the lungs.

(C) Foramen ovale: This opening in the heart's septum lets blood bypass the lungs by flowing directly from the right atrium to the left atrium.

These bypasses close shortly after birth when the baby's lungs become functional.

(C) Foramen ovale: This opening in the heart's septum lets blood bypass the lungs by flowing directly from the right atrium to the left atrium.

These bypasses close shortly after birth when the baby's lungs become functional.

questions.description: Systolic pressure is higher than diastolic pressure due to :

options.description: Volume of blood in the heart is greater during systole
Blood vessels offer resistance to flowing blood during systole
Blood is forced into arteries during systole.

questions.content_html:
Blood pressure is the force of blood pushing against the walls of your arteries. It's measured in two numbers: systolic and diastolic pressure. Systolic pressure is the higher number, representing the pressure in the arteries when the heart contracts (beats) and pumps blood out. Diastolic pressure is the lower number, representing the pressure in the arteries when the heart relaxes between beats.

Systolic pressure is higher than diastolic pressure due to the force of the heart pumping blood into the arteries during systole.

questions.description: The number of QRS complexes observed per minute in an ECG of a person was 85. What could be the heart rate of that person during observation ?
questions.content_html:
The heart rate of the person during observation is 85 beats per minute.

The QRS complex on an electrocardiogram (ECG) represents the electrical activity of the ventricles during contraction. Each QRS complex corresponds to one heartbeat. Therefore, if 85 QRS complexes are observed per minute, the heart rate is 85 beats per minute.
